content: Happy International Transgender Day of Visibility! :tada:
I'm trans (transgender, genderqueer, nonbinary, butch).
Speaking from experience, being trans in open source software communities is not very easy. So as a member of the PMC I wanna represent!
Here's the best thing I've read today for TDOV: https://www.glaad.org/tdovletter
And if you're looking for good places for your donations:

@jackaponte thanks for being part of our community (even though it isn't always easy)!
Thank you @laryn!
The thing is what can we do to make it as easy/safe/pleasant as possible.
These are entirely just my opinion, but I think a number of things can be done by communities to make them more welcoming, inclusive, and comfortable for trans community members.

I'm glad we've got our Code of Conduct and that it specifically mentions transphobic jokes and language as unacceptable behavior (https://github.com/backdrop-ops/conduct/blob/main/code_of_conduct.md)

backdrop-ops/conduct
Backdrop CMS code of conduct and related materials. - backdrop-ops/conduct
https://github.com/backdrop-ops/conduct/blob/master/code_of_conduct.md
Hopefully we'll never have to use the CoC to address transphobia in our community, but if we do, the way we deal with the issue will show a lot about how seriously we take that point in there!

Another important thing we can do is to look for and be aware of issues affecting trans people both in Backdrop and in wider FLOSS (free/libre open source software) communities. There are probably a number of opportunities out there for folks in the Backdrop community to express solidarity with trans people when transphobic stuff is going down in the wider open source world.

Another basic thing that would go a long way: make it standard for folks to share their pronouns in meetings and other spaces. That way folks aren't assuming people's pronouns and using the wrong ones, PLUS it won't just be trans people (like me) saying their pronouns and everyone else not saying them. Instead of singling trans people out, making it standard for everyone to share pronouns during intros puts the responsibility on everyone to not make assumptions.

Final thought from my little brainstorm: if we ever do collect gender demographic info about our community, e.g. a Gender field on profiles or surveys, let's make sure it's actually inclusive and respectful! (Male | Female | Transgender | Other as a single-select field doesn't cut it, heh, see https://www.drupal.org/project/drupalorg/issues/1354764 for more on that...)

@jackaponte thanks for the suggestions. I agree about pronouns and about making it a practice. I'm gonna look at my settings.

And for gender demographic options: just read the link. So you suggest a multi-select. Someone else mentioned another site has a fill-in-the-blank. Which one might work best? (Or some combo - select-or-other?)

@Herb -- yup, back then I suggested a multi-select field; a combo (select-and/or-other) sounds ideal to me. I suggest the multi-select part for folks who want to do analysis of the data gathered through a gender field, since having some "standard" options can help with that aggregation and analysis. But the free-text field lets you get very specific which is great in terms of understanding how folks personally identify and not limiting folks' options.
